summary.seg: MS CUL Kk.5.26 is a miscellany containing Greek texts on music, mathematics and astronomy.

The codex is a composite manuscript, formed of three parts. The first two (ff. 1-63) were copied in the first half of the 16th century, by Giovanni Onorio, scriptor and restaurator of the Vatican Library in the years 1535-1563, and by a contemporary hand. Part III, meanwhile, was copied around the middle of the 15th century.

The manuscript was owned by Francis I, King of France, as is shown by a dedication contained in the beautiful decoration realized by Giovanni Onorio on f. 1r. The codex is no. 44 in the alphabetical catalogue of the Fontainebleau Library of 1550, Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Suppl. gr. 10 (see Omont 1889, p. 17), no. 570 on the methodic catalogue of the same year, Venezia, Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana, Nani 245 (see Omont 1889, p. 305), and is cited in the catalogue of the Greek manuscripts of the Royal Library under King Henry III (1551-1589),
Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, fr. 5585 , f. 126v. It is the only Greek manuscript from the Fontainebleau Library not presently held in Paris (Omont 1889, p. XXIII). Furthermore, Omont identified the Cambridge manuscript as no. 12 in the list of the manuscripts owned by Jérôme Fondule, which were sent to the Fontainebleau Library in 1529 (Omont 1889, p. 371). No. 12 is described as containing Ἀριστείδου καὶ τῶν ἄλλων περὶ μουσικῆς (Aristeides and others on music). Kk.5.26, however, contains the work on music by Aristoxenus, not by Aristeides, consequently this identification, and its possession by Fondule, cannot be regarded as certain.

foliation.p: Leaves are foliated in brown ink and in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto, [i]-[iii] + 1-90 + [90a] + 91-181 + [iv]-[v].

A modern foliation in brown ink in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto, from 1 to 172, has been replaced and supplemented by a pencil one from 55 onwards, due to its numerous inaccuracies (brown ink foliation: [i]-[iii] + 1-54, [54a], 55-62, 62, [62a], 63-87, 87, 88-112, 105, 104, 109, 106, 107-122, 124, 126-150, 152, 155, 154, 155-172 + [iv])

condition.p: In poor condition. Extensive water and humidity stains throughout the manuscript, in particular near the edges of ff. 1r-19v and ff. 174r-[v] verso. The left board of the binding is detached from the spine.

binding.p: Modern western binding. Paper and leather (from the spine) on couched-laminate boards, gold tooled leather spine with title Analeel Graeca M.S. and shelfmark.
Gilded edges with a gauffered foliate design.
On the left pastedown is glued the Royal bookplate; above it, the shelfmark is written in black ink.
binding.condition: The left board is detached from the spine.

accMat.p:
ff. [i] recto-[ii] verso, and [iv] recto-[v] verso, are paper endleaves bound respectively at the beginning and at the end of the manuscript. Watermark:
Letters in a shield ( 23 20 ) in the centre of the folio comparable to Briquet Lettres assemblées 9666 , which is dated to 1550 and localized in Paris..
On f. [i] recto there is a modern annotation in pencil by a librarian describing the collation of the manuscript.
A modern blank leaf, f. [iii], has been added before f. 1, probably in order to protect the decoration on this leaf.

history.provenance: Perhaps no. 12 in the list of manuscripts owned by Fondule, Jérôme Jérôme Fondule , which were sent to the Fontainebleau Library in 1529 (Omont 1889, p. 371). However, no. 12 is described as containing Ἀριστείδου καὶ τῶν ἄλλων περὶ μουσικῆς (Aristeides and others on music), whereas this manuscript contains the work on music by Aristoxenus, not by Aristeides, so the possession of the manuscript by Fondule cannot be regarded as certain.

Owned by Francis I, King of France, 1494-1547 Francis I, King of France (1494-1547) , whose crest is present at f. 1r, with a dedication to him. The book was part of the Library of Fontainebleau and left the royal collection before 1622 (Jackson 2006, p.31).

The manuscript was later owned by John Moore (b. 1646, d. 1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : number 986 in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now MS Oo.7.50(2), compiled by Thomas Tanner after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I King of Great Britain (1660-1727) George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . On the left pastedown is glued the engraved bookplate made by John Pine for the Royal Library (1737).

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws partly on: A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 3, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1858, pp. 694-696; T.J. Mathiesen, Ancient Greek music theory: a catalogue raisonné of manuscripts, München 1988, no. 123.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

The Cambridge Illuminations: ten centuries of book production in the medieval west

"I would be only too happy to collaborate": François Avril on Cambridge manuscripts

monogr.title: Quand la peinture était dans les livres: mélanges en l'honneur de François Avril à l'occasion de la remise du titre de docteur honoris causa de la Freie Universität Berlin

analytic.title: Catalogue of Greek Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the Collections of the United States of America. Part V.3 : Harvard University, The Houghton Library and Andover-Harvard Theological Library

summary.seg:
This part of the manuscript, containing the Elements of Harmony by the fourth-century Aristotelian philosopher Aristoxenus, was copied by Giovanni Onorio da Maglie, who also executed the illumination. Dedicated to Francis I, King of France, this is an example of Giovanni Onorio's most refined work, usually destined for high-ranking patrons (see Agati 2001, pp. 104-109). The scribe wrote this same text with a very similar illumination in two other manuscripts, for different patrons: in MS
Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Barb. gr. 265 , copied in 1543 and dedicated to Cardinal Matteo Cervini, and in MS
Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Vat. gr. 221 , copied in the years 1535-1549 (Agati 2001, p. 288) for Pope Paul III Farnese.

msItem.author: Aristoxenus
msItem.title: Elements of Harmony
Elementa harmonica
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Τῆς περὶ μέλους ἐπιστήμης πολυμεροῦς οὔσης
msItem.explicit: f. 18r πρὸς ἄλληλα ἢ τοσαυταχῶς ῥᾴδιον συνιδεῖν.
msItem.note: ff. 18v-19v are blank

msItem.title: Book 1
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Ἀριστοξένου πρὸ τῶν ἁρμονικῶν στοιχείων πρῶτον

msItem.title: Book 3
msItem.rubric: f. 14v l. 6 Ἀριστοξένου ἁρμονικῶν στοιχείων τρίτον

support.material: Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark ff. 1r-19v Arrows surmounted by a six-point star ( 73 27 ) in the centre of the folio identical to Agati 2001, p. 130, watermark 8a, which is found in manuscripts copied by Giovanni Onorio in the years 1524-1550; the watermark is also similar to Harlfinger Flèche 19 , which is dated to 1534-1536.

supportDesc.foliation: A pagination in Arabic numerals from 1 to 35 is part of running heads written by the scribe on ff. 1r-18r, at the top of the pages. They comprise the name of the author in red ink on the verso, the title of the work with the number of the book in red ink on the recto, the page number in Arabic numerals in black ink.

collation.p: Part I consists of 2 ternions and 2 binions. The first quire lacks its first leaf, without loss of text.

list.item: Quire 16-1 ff. 1-5 (first leaf excised, probably blank)

collation.signatures: Modern signatures in pencil, in Latin letters, from A to D, by a librarian, on the lower margin, right, recto, of the first leaf of each quire.

supportDesc.condition: Humidity stains are present along the external borders and in the upper part of all the leaves.

handNote.p: Hand A: the text is written by Giovanni Onorio (1535-1563) Onorio, Giovanni, -1563 , (RGK I, 174. See also RGK II, 232; RGK III, 286) in a minuscule, very regular and calligraphic.
The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red and in gold.
The scribe wrote variants to the text in the margins throughout, often preceded by the indication ἐν ἄλλῳ in red ink, see e.g. f. 3r.
The titles are written in majuscule letters.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 1r there is a pyle with a golden contour; in the pyle, coloured in red, blue and green, there are gilded linear motifs, lilies, two cartouches, on which is written, in gold, the motto of Francis I of France Erit Christianorum lumen in igne at auro praestantior.

On the lower part of f. 1r, Francis I's emblem is enclosed in a laurel crown, with two putti at its sides; beneath, the dedication to king Francis is written in gold on a blue band with gilded frame: Francisci regis bibliothecae dicatus. The putti appear to belong to group "a" in Giovanni Onorio da Maglie's production (see Agati 2001, p. 106).

On f. 1r gilded initial on a coloured ground, divided in 4 squares, blue and red; in the ground, pen-flourished vegetal gilded decoration. On ff. 8r and 14v, initials in red ink decorated with a simple vegetal motif.
Around the titles on ff. 8r and 14v, three small vegetal motifs in red ink.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was copied by Giovanni Onorio in the first half of the 16th century, in the years 1524-1550, probably in Rome. The watermark of this part is identical with one present in Giovanni Onorio's manuscripts in that period.

msItem.author: Artabasda, Nicolaus
msItem.title: Letter to Theodore Tzabouches of Klazomenai on arithmetical computation
msItem.rubric: f. 20r Τῷ ὑπερλίαν ἐκθύμως φιλουμένῳ τῷ Κλαζομενεῖ Τζαβούκη Θεοδώρῳ, ὁ Νικόλαος Ἀρτάβασδος Σμυρνόθεν, ἐκ Βυζαντίδος ὁ Ῥαβδᾶς γράφει τόδε
msItem.incipit: f. 20r Τὴν δήλωσιν τῶν ἐν τοῖς ἀριθμοῖς ζητημάτων λαμπρότατέ μοι

msItem.title: Mathematical problem (no. 5 in Hoche's edition)
msItem.rubric: f. 35v Μέθοδος δι’ ἧς ἀστείως εὑρήσεις ὁποῖον ἀριθμὸν ἔχει τις ἐπὶ νοῦν
msItem.incipit: f. 35v Ἀριθμὸν ὁντιναοῦν τῶν ἀπὸ τοῦ ζ΄ μέχρι τοῦ ρε΄
msItem.explicit: f. 36r καὶ τρίτον χρυσίνου καὶ δωδέκατον καὶ ἑκατοστοενενηκοστοδεύτερον ἕν.
msItem.note: Edition of the text in: Nicomachi Geraseni Pythagorei Introductionis arithmeticae libri II, ed. by R.G. Hoche (Lipsiae, 1866), pp. 152 l. 4-154
are blank.

msItem.author: Artabasda, Nicolaus
msItem.title: Letter to George Chatzykes on the value of the Greek alphabetical numbers
msItem.rubric: f. 44r Παράδοσις σύντομος καὶ σαφεστάτη τῆς ψηφοφορικῆς ἐπιστήμης σχεδιασθεῖσα ἐν Βυζαντίδι τῇ Κωνσταντίνου, παρὰ Νικολάου Σμυρναίου Ἀρταβάσδου ἀριθμητικοῦ καὶ γεωμέτρου τοῦ Ῥαβδᾶ· αἰτήσει τοῦ πανσεβάστου ἐπὶ τῶν δεήσεων κυροῦ Γεωργίου τοῦ Χατζύκη, ῥᾴστη τοῖς ἐθέλουσι ταύτην μετελθεῖν, ἥτις καὶ ἔχει οὕτως
msItem.incipit: f. 44r Τὴν δήλωσιν τῶν ἐν τοῖς ἀριθμοῖς ζητημάτων πανσέβαστε
msItem.explicit: f. 50v b l. 28 εἶτα τὸ γʹʹ, τὸ δʹʹ, τὸ εʹʹ, τὸ ϛʹʹ, τὸ ζʹʹ, καὶ ἑξῆς.
msItem.note: There is a lacuna in the text before f. 50v, P. Tannery, Sciences exactes chez les Byzantins, in: Mémoires scientifiques 4 (1920), pp. 86-116 (p. 114 ll. 1-6).
The text is accompanied by tables

msItem.author: Argyros, Isaac, approximately 1305-approximately 1375
msItem.title: Two mathematical problems (nr. 2-3 in Hoche's edition)
msItem.note: Edition of the text in: Nicomachi Geraseni Pythagorei Introductionis arithmeticae libri II, ed. by R.G. Hoche (Lipsiae, 1866), pp. 149 l. 10-154
The attribution to the author is not certain
ff. 51v-52v are blank.

msItem.incipit: f. 50v Πῶς ἂν ἐκ μεθόδου προχειρότατα γινώσκοι

msItem.rubric: f. 51r Τοῦ αὐτοῦ Ἰσαὰκ, περὶ συνθέσεως ἀριθμῶν ἐν ἴσῃ ἐκκειμένων ὑπεροχῇ
msItem.incipit: f. 51r Ἀριθμῶν ὅσων δήποτε ἐκκειμένων ἐν ἴσῃ ὑπεροχῇ
msItem.explicit: f. 51r καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν ἄλλων ὁμοίως.

msItem.author: Planudes, Maximus, approximately 1260-approximately 1310
msItem.title: Great Calculation According to the Indians
Ars calculatoria secundum Indos
msItem.rubric: f. 53r Ψῆφος Ἰνδικὴ λεγομένη. Μαξίμου μοναχοῦ, τοῦ Πλανούδη ψηφοιφορία κατ’ Ἰνδούς ἡ λεγομένη μεγάλη
msItem.explicit: f. 60v ἐξαλείφειν τῷ δακτύλῳ, ἑτέρους δέ
msItem.note: The text is incomplete, ending at Maxime Planude. Le Grand Calcul selon les Indiens, ed. by A. Allard (Louvain-la-Neuve, 1981), p. 73 l. 10
After the text, at f. 61r there are tables comparing the Attic numbers, the Greek numbers and numbers similar to those used by Planudes

msItem.author: Artabasda, Nicolaus
msItem.title: Letter to George Chatzykes on the value of the Greek alphabetical numbers, excerpt
msItem.incipit: f. 61v Καὶ οὕτω μὲν ὁ ἁπλοῦς
msItem.explicit: f. 61v εἶτα τὸ γʹʹ, τὸ δʹʹ, τὸ εʹʹ, τὸ ϛʹʹ, τὸ ζʹʹ, καὶ ἑξῆς.
msItem.note: An extract from the text, P. Tannery, Sciences exactes chez les Byzantins, in: Mémoires scientifiques 4 (1920), pp. 86-116 (p. 114 ll. 1-17)

msItem.title: Mathematical texts
msItem.explicit: f. 62v εὑρήσεις ἀκριβῶς τὴν ἐκάστου ὁνομασίας.
msItem.note: After the text, the scribe wrote some abbreviations of mathematical terms with the corresponding word
ff. 63r-63v are blank

support.material:
ff. 20-63 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 27-43, 52-63 Anchor in a circle surmounted by a six-point star, with countermark with letter M and a cross (it is never possible to see it completely) ( 66 45 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable to Sosower Ancre 58 , which is dated to ca. 1543 and to Harlfinger Ancre 51 , which is dated to 1540 and 1541.
ff. 44-51 Two arrows surmounted by a six-point star with countermark with letter M and a cross (it is never possible to see it completely) ( 95 45 ) in the centre of the folio, comparable to Sosower Flèche 27 , which is dated to ca. 1542.

collation.p: Part II consists of 5 quaternions and 1 binion.

supportDesc.condition: Humidity stains are present along the external borders and in the upper part of all the leaves.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 20r-30r, 44r-51r, 55r-62v: a single column of 32 lines 220 140

handNote.p: ff. 20r-30r, 44r-51r Hand B: informal minuscule, fairly vertical, characterised by a striking contrast between the normal size of letters and some letters of bigger size, in particular, tau and gamma, especially when in the first line of the folio (see, for example, f. 46r ). Vertical lines tend to become oblique, to slant decidedly to the left and to expand below the line (see letters csi, ro, zeta).
The scribe does not write iota subscript.
The text is written in brown ink, titles and initials in red.

ff. 55r-62v Hand C: an informal minuscule, slanting to the left, characterised by a contrast between the normal size of letters and some letters of bigger size, such as tau, gamma. Forms of letters and ligatures are similar to those of hand B. Vertical strokes tend to become oblique, to slant decidedly to the left (see letters as zeta, delta, csi).
The scribe does not write iota subscript.
The text is written in brown ink, titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: On ff. 20r and 53r there are rectangular headpieces in red ink; the first is filled with triangular motifs; the second is filled with a repetitive geometrical pattern.
Friezes in a rope motif in red ink are present on ff. 35r, 44r, and 50v. The rope on f. 44r has a dragon head at the right-hand end.
Thick red-ink initials in ekthesis with a vegetal decoration, see ff. 20r, 44r, and 55r. Minor initials in red ink, sometimes simply decorated, see e.g. ff. 34v-35r.

additions.p: On the right margin of f. 20r there is an annotation by another hand.

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was copied by two contemporary hands, between the third decade and the middle of the 16th century, as indicated by the watermarks.

msItem.author: Argyros, Isaac, approximately 1305-approximately 1375
msItem.title: On the square roots of nonsquare numbers
De inventione quadraticorum laterum irrationabilium numerorum quadratorum
msItem.rubric: f. 64r Ἰσαὰκ μοναχοῦ τοῦ Ἀργυροῦ μέθοδος ὅπως δεῖ εὑρίσκειν τὰς πλευρὰς τῶν μὴ ῥητῶν τετραγώνων ἀριθμῶν
msItem.incipit: f. 64r Τῶν μὲν τετραγώνων ἀριθμῶν τῶν καὶ ῥητῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 68r Καὶ ἐπὶ τῶν ἄλλων ὁμοίως
msItem.note:
The text is followed by:
f. 68r a list of Persian numbers ( Ἀριθμοὶ Περσικοί)
f. 68v a table of the square roots, incomplete ( Μοναχοῦ Ἰσαὰκ τοῦ Ἀργυροῦ κανόνιον περὶ τῆς τετραγωνικῆς πλευρᾶς)

msItem.title: Short texts on mathematics
msItem.incipit: f. 69r Ἐπειδήπερ οἱ πολλαπλασμιασμοὶ τῶν τε μοιρῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 73v l. 18 ὅν ἔχει ὁ α πρὸς τὸν β, ὅπερ ἔδει δεῖξαι
msItem.note: The texts on ff. 69v l. 17-71v l. 12, which, in the title, are attributed to Michael Psellus Psellus, Michael ( Εἰς τοὺς ὅρους τοὺ ι΄ βιβλίου τοῦ Εὐκλείδου, τοῦ ὑπάτου τῶν φιλοσόφων Μιχαὴλ τοῦ Ψελλοῦ), are the same as those found in MS Venezia, Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana, gr. Z 333, ff. 86v-88r, where they have been copied by Bessarion and are also attributed to Psellos.

msItem.author: Theon, of Alexandria, active 364
msItem.title: Commentary on the Almagest (book 1, hypomnema 2)
Commentarium in Ptolemaei syntaxin mathematicam
msItem.rubric: f. 73v Θέωνος Ἀλεξανδρέως ἐξήγησις εἰς τὸ πρῶτον βιβλίον τῆς μεγάλης τῷ ὄντι καὶ θαυμαστῆς τοῦ Πτολαιμαίου συντάξεως τὸ προοίμιον, εἰς τὸν υἱὸν αὐτοῦ Ἐπιφάνιον οὕτω καλούμενον
msItem.incipit: f. 73v Συνεχέστερον προτρεπόμενος παρὰ τῶν ἀκροατῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 176r διὰ τὸ τὴν ἰσημερινὴν ὥραν, χρόνων εἶναι, ιε. Ὅπερ ἔδει δεῖξαι.
msItem.note: The text is not complete. It ends at: A. Rome, Commentaires de Pappus et de Théon d'Alexandrie sur l'Almageste, II (Città del Vaticano, 1936), p. 624 l. 18
The text is accompanied by diagrams
f. 176v is blank

msItem.title: Hippiatrica Berolinensia, excerptum
msItem.incipit: f. 177r Ἰατρεσάμενος ἐν τοῖς τάγμασι τοῖς ἐπὶ τοῦ Ἴστρου ποταμοῦ
msItem.explicit: f. 181r τῇ ὀριγάνῳ, καλύψαντα τὴν κεφαλὴν
msItem.note:
There is only a part of the text:
Corpus hippiatricorum Graecorum, 1, ed. by K. Hoppe and E. Oder (Leipzig, 1924) (repr. 1971), pp. 1-17 l. 22
At f. 181r l. 7 there is a lacuna, καθ’ ἡμέραν μέχρι ἡμερῶν [...] ἧς καὶ σημεῖα φέρεται (Hoppe-Oder 1924), p. 16 l. 19-17 l. 2

The title was added by another hand; the text is attributed to
Apsyrtus Absyrtus, veterinario

support.material:
ff. 64-181 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 64-88, 94-181 Shissors ( 75 33 ) in the centre of the folio very similar to Harlfinger Ciseaux 43 , which is dated to 1452.
ff. 89-93 Crown with letters S h ( 35 25 ) in the centre of the folio, very similar to Harlfinger Couronne 31 , which is dated to 1463.

collation.p: Part III consists of 14 quaternions, and 1 quaternion which has lost the last leaf without loss of text.

list.item: Quire 258-1 ff. 175-181(ιε΄) (last leaf excised, probably blank.)

signatures.p: Greek signatures in black or red ink, original to the production of this part of the manuscript from α΄ (1, f. 64r) to ιε΄ (15, f. 175r), on the lower margin, centre, recto, of the first leaf of each quire.

Later signatures in modern pencil, probably by a librarian, on the lower margin, right, recto, of the first leaf of each quire, from α΄ (1, f. 64r) to θ΄ (9, f. 127r). This same hand added a sign + on the lower margin, right, recto, of the 5th leaf of each quire.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are yellowed (in particular f. 64r). Humidity stains are present along the external borders and in the upper part of all the leaves. ff. 88v-93v have water stains in the gutter. The red ink is smeared in some places.

handNote.p: ff. 64r-176r, 177r-181r Hand D: the texts have been written in an informal minuscule, vertical, regular, of small size.
The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: Thick red-ink initials, decorated with vegetal motifs and pearls: see, for example, f. 64r, f. 72r.
Minor initials, thick, in red ink: see, for example, f. 101r.
The text is accompanied by geometrical illustrations, traced in black, with letters and terms in red (see, for example, ff. 82v, 84r).

additions.p: On f. 177r, a later hand of the 16th century wrote a title for the work in the upper margin.
On f. 181v a later hand copied a short part of the last text of the manuscript, the Hippiatrica (Hoppe-Oder 1924, p. 10 ll. 16-18).
On the lower margin f. 181r, in modern pencil, a later hand added a reference to the edition of the preceding text ( Hippiatrica) by Ruel (Basel, 1537).

origin.p: This part of the manuscript was copied around the middle of the 15th century, as suggested by the watermarks.
